psychiatry into the courtroom by law. viciating the integrity of the thera- peutic process." he said. "It puts the whole profession in jeopardy "
The most critical concerns center around fears that patients either would conceal their true feelings from psychiatrists or avoid treatment entirely. The prospect of others fol- lowing the example of Dr. Lifschutz was not ruled out by Dr. David W. Al- len, former president of the Northern California Psychiatric Association. "My impression is that psychiatnsts are keeping fewer and fewer records these days. simply because they are. under some circumstances. vulner- able to court subpoena." he said.
HEPATITIS
TELLING A FROM B
Two new serologic tests using an ex- tract of marmoset liver infected with human type A (infectious) hepatitis virus promise to simplify diagnosis of hepatitis A and may be valuable tools in the study of its epidemiology The developments. reported by Dr. Maur- ice Hilleman, director of viral and cell biology research at the Merck Insti- tute for Therapeutic Research In West Point. Pa , may eventually lead to a hepatitis A vaccine
Dr. Hilleman and his associates had shown a causal relationship be- tween a human hepattis A virus they had isolated in marmosets and hepa- tilis A in people (Www. Apr. 20, "73. p.5) Extending these studies, the Merck researchers found that two tests-for immune adherence and for complement fixation-detected anti- beidies in patients soon after the on- set of hepatitis A While the comple- ment.fixing antibodies appeared slightly earlier than the immune.ad. herence ones, the latter test was far more sensitive. Dr Hilleman reported in Milan at an International Assoc. ation of Biological Standardization
symposium on viral hepatitis
The immune adherence test de- pends on red cell clumping Both tests detect hepatitis A antibodies but not hepatitis B ones, providing definitive differentiation between the two diseases. Dr. Hilleman said.
Dr Saut Krugman, professor of pe- diatrics at New York University. hailed the findings as "a very impor- tant piece of work. If these observa- tions are confirmed and if the antigen can be made available, we'll have a test to diagnose hepatitis A just as we can hepatitis B.""
The Merck researchers are not the first to identity the A virus. In 1973 a group at the National Institutes of Health detected it in stools of pa. tients with the disease (MwN, Dec. 21. '73, p. 20). They used immune elec- tron microscopy to detect antibody formation, but this is a research tool few clinical laboratories have.
The new tests are not expected to be useful in screening blond donors, Dr. Hilleman noted. In any event, the risk of transfusion hepatitis is not as great with the A type as it is with B. "No one has yet been able to confirm that a carrier state exists with: virus A as has been done with virus B." com- mented Dr. Krugman.
ALCOHOLISM
MILLS FACES HIS PROBLEM Rep. Wilbur Mills' admission that he is an alcoholic places him in the company of an estimated nine million Americans who misuse alcohol, ac- cording to the National Clear- Inghouse on Alcoholism Information. But the prognosis for his recovery is good. "While the development of al- coholism is not unheard of in a man Mills' age [65], It is considered rare." says Dr. Donald W. Goodwin, profes- continued
Researchers have developed two tests to distinguish between hepatitis A [left) and hepatitis B The newtechniques will be helpful diagnostic tools
